user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of setup_epoll_to_listen:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
setup_epoll_to_listen (struct MHD_Daemon *daemon)
{
  struct epoll_event event;
  MHD_socket ls;

  mhd_assert (MHD_D_IS_USING_EPOLL_ (daemon));
  mhd_assert (0 == (daemon->options & MHD_USE_THREAD_PER_CONNECTION));
  mhd_assert ( (! MHD_D_IS_USING_THREADS_ (daemon)) || \
               (MHD_INVALID_SOCKET != (ls = daemon->listen_fd)) || \
               MHD_ITC_IS_VALID_ (daemon->itc) );
  daemon->epoll_fd = setup_epoll_fd (daemon);
  if (! MHD_D_IS_USING_THREADS_ (daemon)
      && (0 != (daemon->options & MHD_USE_AUTO)))
  {
    /* Application requested "MHD_USE_AUTO", probably MHD_get_fdset() will be
       used.
       Make sure that epoll FD is suitable for fd_set.
       Actually, MHD_get_fdset() is allowed for MHD_USE_EPOLL direct,
       but most probably direct requirement for MHD_USE_EPOLL means that
       epoll FD will be used directly. This logic is fuzzy, but better
       than nothing with current MHD API. */
    if (! MHD_D_DOES_SCKT_FIT_FDSET_ (daemon->epoll_fd, daemon))
    {
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
      MHD_DLOG (daemon,
                _ ("The epoll FD is too large to be used with fd_set.\n"));
#endif /* HAVE_MESSAGES */
      return MHD_NO;
    }
  }
  if (-1 == daemon->epoll_fd)
    return MHD_NO;
#if defined(HTTPS_SUPPORT) && defined(UPGRADE_SUPPORT)
  if (0 != (MHD_ALLOW_UPGRADE & daemon->options))
  {
    daemon->epoll_upgrade_fd = setup_epoll_fd (daemon);
    if (MHD_INVALID_SOCKET == daemon->epoll_upgrade_fd)
      return MHD_NO;
  }
#endif /* HTTPS_SUPPORT && UPGRADE_SUPPORT */
  if ( (MHD_INVALID_SOCKET != (ls = daemon->listen_fd)) &&
       (! daemon->was_quiesced) )
  {
    event.events = EPOLLIN | EPOLLRDHUP;
    event.data.ptr = daemon;
    if (0 != epoll_ctl (daemon->epoll_fd,
                        EPOLL_CTL_ADD,
                        ls,
                        &event))
    {
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
      MHD_DLOG (daemon,
                _ ("Call to epoll_ctl failed: %s\n"),
                MHD_socket_last_strerr_ ());
#endif
      return MHD_NO;
    }
    daemon->listen_socket_in_epoll = true;
  }

  if (MHD_ITC_IS_VALID_ (daemon->itc))
  {
    event.events = EPOLLIN | EPOLLRDHUP;
    event.data.ptr = _MHD_DROP_CONST (epoll_itc_marker);
    if (0 != epoll_ctl (daemon->epoll_fd,
                        EPOLL_CTL_ADD,
                        MHD_itc_r_fd_ (daemon->itc),
                        &event))
    {
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
      MHD_DLOG (daemon,
                _ ("Call to epoll_ctl failed: %s\n"),
                MHD_socket_last_strerr_ ());
#endif
      return MHD_NO;
    }
  }
  return MHD_YES;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Other fragments in the function are simple variable declarations, single assignments or calls (e.g. 'struct epoll_event event;', 'MHD_socket ls;', 'daemon->epoll_fd = setup_epoll_fd (daemon);', calls to logging macros guarded by #ifdef, and setting event fields). These do not introduce control-flow branches that would be inherently unreachable on their own. Preprocessor-guarded sections not included here are compile-time excluded and therefore not part of the compiled control flow; they should be handled separately in their respective compilation configurations. The listed suspicious fragments are the branching/return sites or assert with embedded assignment that could produce unreachable paths or merit investigation for logically impossible branches under project invariants.
